    Creating an annotated map Creating postcards

    Creating an annotated map

    creating-an-annotated-map.Rmd

    In this vignette, you will learn how to add new information to a map. Here, we retrieve a map for Berlin and get data for traffic accidents from govdata.de.

    library(cartographr)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(sf)
library(osmdata)

    First, we load the locations of traffic accidents in Berlin for the year 2021.

    data("berlinaccidents") 

df_accidents <- berlinaccidents |> 
 st_as_sf(coords = c("XGCSWGS84", "YGCSWGS84"), crs=4326, remove = F) |>
 slice_head(n = 500) |> 
 mutate(type = as.factor(ifelse(IstRad == 1, "Bike involved", "No bike involved")))

df_accidents |> head()
#> Simple feature collection with 6 features and 24 fields
#> Geometry type: POINT
#> Dimension:     XY
#> Bounding box:  xmin: 13.31652 ymin: 52.43995 xmax: 13.52575 ymax: 52.53803
#> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
#> # A tibble: 6 × 25
#>   OBJECTID  LAND   BEZ LOR_ab_2021 UJAHR UMONAT USTUNDE UWOCHENTAG UKATEGORIE
#>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>
#> 1   219249    11     3     3701658  2021     11      18          2          3
#> 2   219248    11     7     7501134  2021     12      19          7          3
#> 3   219247    11     4     4100101  2021     12      17          4          3
#> 4   219246    11     4     4501041  2021     12      15          7          3
#> 5   219243    11    11    11501339  2021     12       9          5          3
#> 6   219241    11     1     1100308  2021     12      22          5          3
#> # ℹ 16 more variables: UART <dbl>, UTYP1 <dbl>, ULICHTVERH <dbl>, IstRad <dbl>,
#> #   IstPKW <dbl>, IstFuss <dbl>, IstKrad <dbl>, IstGkfz <dbl>,
#> #   IstSonstige <dbl>, USTRZUSTAND <dbl>, LINREFX <dbl>, LINREFY <dbl>,
#> #   XGCSWGS84 <dbl>, YGCSWGS84 <dbl>, geometry <POINT [°]>, type <fct>

    Setup the map parameters

    We have to provide longitude, latitude. Furthermore, we define the extend of the OSM data in meters in get_osmdata().

    osmdata::get_overpass_url()
#> [1] "https://overpass-api.de/api/interpreter"
osmdata::set_overpass_url("https://overpass.kumi.systems/api/interpreter")


df_berlin <- tibble(lat = c(52.516628),
       lon = c(13.378704),
       y_distance = c(2400),
       x_distance = c(2400*sqrt(2)),
       name = c("berlin"))

osm <- get_osmdata(df_berlin$lat, df_berlin$lon, df_berlin$y_distance,df_berlin$x_distance)
#> Getting data, be patient with requests failing..
#> Creating street network..
#> Construct buildings..
#> Fill in water..
#> Plant trees..
#> Beach, parking..

    Preprocess the osm data

    The function preprocess_map() prepares the osm data by joining, preparing and removing props on the map.

    osm_pps <- osm |> preprocess_map()

    Plot the map

    plot_map() generates a ggplot2 object using the color theme set as parameter. That means that we can easily adjust the plot using ggplot2 commands and also add new information to the map. Note, that when adding a new geom, the coordinate system is reset, thus we need to reset the boundaries of the map using adjust_display().

    p <- osm_pps |> plot_map(color = get_color("bwinv"), scaling = get_scaling("A3"))  +
  # add geom with coordinates of accidents
  geom_point(data = suppressMessages(sf::st_intersection(df_accidents,
                                                               osm_pps$my_bbox |> sf::st_as_sfc())),
             aes(x=XGCSWGS84,y=YGCSWGS84,color=type), size=5)+ # color="#FF474D")+
  
  # reset the boundary box after adding a new geom
  adjust_display(osm_pps) +
  
  # Set theme for labels
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 24,hjust = 0,face = "bold",colour = "#292e28"),
    plot.margin = margin(t = 5, r = 5, b = 5, l = 5, unit = "mm"),
    plot.caption = element_text(face="plain",size=10),
    legend.position = "top",
    legend.justification = c("right","top"),
    legend.margin = margin(-8, 0, 0, 0, unit = "mm")
  ) + 
  
  # Set labels
  labs(title = "Traffic accidents in Berlin (2021)",
       color = "Type",
       caption="Dataset: govdata.de\n© Stadt Berlin (2024)")

p

    Save map

    save_map() can be used to store the print-ready plot object to the disk as a drawn object in pdf format. Default mode for storing the output is portrait mode. Here, we want landscape orientation and can do so using the orientation parameter.

    save_map(plot = p, filename=paste0("~/berlin_A3_bw.pdf"), orientation = "landscape")
